title: 105_hr1728
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Park System New Area Studies Act" and includes a study of new park system areas. The National Park System General Authorities Act is amended to include a new subsection for studies of potential park additions to be submitted annually to Congress. The National Park System General Authorities Act is amended to include a new subsection for studies of potential park additions to be submitted annually to Congress. The Secretary shall consider areas with national significance, suitability, and feasibility for inclusion in the National Park System, giving special attention to themes, sites, and resources not adequately represented. No new studies for park inclusion can begin without specific authorization from Congress. The National Park Service retains the authority to conduct preliminary assessments, gather data, and provide technical assistance. The National Park System General Authorities Act is amended to include a new subsection for studies of potential park additions to be submitted annually to Congress. The Secretary of the Interior shall complete the study for each area for potential inclusion in the National Park System within 3 complete fiscal years following the date of enactment of specific legislation providing for the study of such area. Each study shall involve public involvement, including at least one public meeting. The Secretary of the Interior shall conduct studies for potential park additions, considering national significance, suitability, and feasibility. Factors like resource rarity, threats, and existing protections are evaluated in each study. The Secretary of the Interior conducts studies for potential park additions, evaluating factors such as public use potential, interpretive and educational potential, costs, socioeconomic impacts, public support, and long-term resource protection. Consideration is given to whether National Park Service management or alternative protection by other public agencies or the private sector is appropriate for the area. The Secretary of the Interior conducts studies for potential park additions, evaluating factors such as public use potential, interpretive and educational potential, costs, socioeconomic impacts, public support, and long-term resource protection. Each study must identify the most effective and efficient alternative for resource protection and public enjoyment, comply with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969, and include a recommendation for the Secretary's preferred management option. At the beginning of each calendar year, the Secretary must submit a list of areas to Congress along with the annual budget submission. The Secretary of the Interior submits lists of areas previously studied for historical and natural resources to the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources in order of priority for National Park System addition. The Secretary considers threats to resource values, cost factors, and other specified criteria. $2,000,000 is authorized for carrying out the designated subsections. The House of Representatives passed the bill on August 3, 1998. Clerk Robin H. Carle attested to it.
